1% ANNUAL REPONE
Prin Nail Arod. Sti. USA Vol. 17, pp. 9010-9014. November 1990 Medical Sciences
FILE COPY CUcks CTR 4501
Advanced protein glycosylation induces transendothelial human monocyte chemotaxis and secretion of platelet-derived growth factor: Role in vascular disease of diabetes and aging
tarteriosclerosis/atherosclerosis/macrophages/migration/thave remodeling)
M. KIRSTEIN". J. BRETT', S. RADOFF"; S. OGAWA+. D. STERN', AND H. VLASSARA" "Laboratory of Medical Bauchemistry. The Rockefeller L'moveruly. New York, NY 10021; and "Department of Physiology. Rover Physiology Laborsiones. Columbus L'ameruty. College of Physicians and Surgeces, New York, NY 10032
Communicated by Mociyn McCarty. August 20, 1990
ABSTRACT Diabetes and aging are commonly accompa- nled by arterio- and atherosclerosis. Infiltration of the arterial subendothelial Intima by macrophages/monocytes is no im- portant early event preceding the development of atheromatous lesions: these macrophages are known to produce mitogenic factors in early atherosclerotic lesions. It has been previously shown that, over time, vascular matrix accumulates proteins nonenzymatically modified by advanced glycosylation end products (AGEst. In view of the fact that macrophages/ munocyits have AGE-specific receptors associated with the expression of several growth factors, we Investigated the pos- sibility that AGEs medinte Initial monocyte-vessel wall Inter- actions that occur before overt formation of vascular lesions. This study demonstrates that ti in vitro- and in vivo-formed AGEs are chemotactic for human blood monocytes. (if) sub- endothelial AGEs can selectively induce monocyte migration across an intact endothelial cell monolayer, and (iii) subsequent monocyte Interaction with AGE-containing matrix results in the expression of platelet-derived growth factor. These results support the existing hypothesis that in vivo-forming glucose- derived protein adducts can act as signals for the normal turnover of senescent tissue protein by means of the AGE- specific receptor system. Time-dependent glucose-Induced dep- osition of AGEs on matrix proteins may, promote monocyte Infiltration into the subendothellum. Subsequent AGE-trig- gered macrophage activation and consequent elaboration of proliferative factors muy normally coordinate remodeling but may also lead to the diverse pathogenic changes typical of arterio- and atherosclerosis In diabetic or aging populations.
Proteins exposed to ambient glucose undergo nonenzymatic glycosylation. leading to the progressive formation of highly reactive late addition products termed advanced glycosyia- tion end products (AGEs). Steady accumulation of AGEs on proteins with relatively long half-lives in many tissues. cs- pecially on subendothelial basement-membrane proteins. oc- curs with normal aging (1) and at an accelerated rate in diabetes (2), suggesting a possible etiologic role in the patho- genesis of the vascular complications associated with these conditions.
Although monocytes are involved in the normal mainte- nuance and remodeling of the vascular basement membrane 1.31. they have also been causally implicated in the pathogen- euis of vascular lesions in atherosclerosis (4-6). Monocytes/ macrophages express AGE-specific receptors that mediate endocytosis and degradation of AGE-modified proteins (7). After AGE binding and intracellular processing. monocytes synthesize and secrete growth-promoting cytokines such as cacheclin/tumor necrosis factor, interleukin 1. and insulin-
The publication costs of this article were defrayed in part by page charge payment. This article must therefore be hereby marked ""advertisement"" in accordance with 18 U.S.C. 01734 solely to indicate this fact.
like growth factor 1 (8. 9): Because this mechanism could be fundamental to vessel-wall tissue homeostasis before the manifestations of vascular pathology. it was important to determine whether AGEs promoted monocyte-vessel wall interactions. leading to monocyte migration into the suben- dothelium and the subsequent activation of these monocytes.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Preparation of AGE-Modified Bovine Serum Albumin. AGE-bovine serum albumin (BSA) was prepared by incu- bating BSA (fraction V. low endotoxin: Bochringer Mann- heimlin phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) with 50 mM glucose 6-phosphate (Glc-6-P) as described 47). Normal control BSA was incubated under the same conditions without Glc-6-P. Fluorescence spectra of AGE-BSA tat 460 nm upon excita. tion at 390 nm) indicated increased glycosylation as a func- tion of time (see Results). At 42 days AGE-BSA contained 80 arbitrary fluorescence units (AFL' per 100 ug of protein). whereas unmodified BSA maintained background levels (4 AFU per 100 ug of protein). For selected experiments samples (20 mg each) incubated with 50 mM Glc-6-P for 3 and 6 days were reduced with sodium borohydride as described (10).
Preparation of AGE-Modified Low Density Lipoprotein (LDL). LDL was prepared from pooled normolipidemic human serum by density-gradient ultracentrifugation (11). LDL was glycosylated in vitro (AGE-LDL) as described above for 3 weeks in the presence of the antioxidants butylated hydroxytoluene (20 uMI and EDTA (0.5 mM) and under a blanket of N2 in scaled tubes. Oxidized LDL was prepared by incubating LDL for 3 weeks in the absence of antioxidants or glucose. The amount of lipid peroxidation was estimated as thiobarbituric acid-reactive material (12). and the extent of advanced nonenzy matic glycosylation of the LDL samples was determined by fluorescence as de- scribed above. AGE-modified LDL exhibited three times greater fluorescence (30 AFU per 100 ug of protein) than unmodified LDL 19 AFU per 100 as of proteinl.
Preparation of Peripheral Nerve Myelin. Human peripheral nerve myelin obtained at autopsy from a 5-month-old normal infant. a 63-year-old nondiabetic. and a 61-year-old diabetic was isolated by standard procedures (13). Fluorescence studies of the myelin from the 61-year-old diabetic indicated J-fold greater AGE-levels (156 AFU per 100 ug of protein) than the age-matched normal individual 150 AFU per 100 ps of protein). which produced 3.5-fold greater fluorescence
Abbreviations: AGEs. advanced glycosylation end products: FMLP. N-formylmethionylleucylphenylalanine: LDL. low density lipopro- tein: PDGF. platelet-derived growth factor: BSA. bovine serum albumin: AFU, arbitrary fluorescence units: GBSS, Gey's balanced salt solution; Gk-&-P. glucose 6-phosphate.
9010
PUBLICATIONS

Columbus L'ameruty. College of Physicians and Surgeces, New York, NY 10032
Communicated by Mociyn McCarty. August 20, 1990
ABSTRACT
Diabetes and aging are commonly accompa-
nled by arterio- and atherosclerosis. Infiltration of the arterial
subendothelial Intima by macrophages/monocytes is no im-
portant early event preceding the development of atheromatous
lesions: these macrophages are known to produce mitogenic
factors in early atherosclerotic lesions. It has been previously
shown that, over time, vascular matrix accumulates proteins
nonenzymatically modified by advanced glycosylation end
products (AGEst. In view of the fact that macrophages/
munocyits have AGE-specific receptors associated with the
expression of several growth factors, we Investigated the pos-
sibility that AGEs medinte Initial monocyte-vessel wall Inter-
actions that occur before overt formation of vascular lesions.
This study demonstrates that ti in vitro- and in vivo-formed
AGEs are chemotactic for human blood monocytes. (if) sub-
endothelial AGEs can selectively induce monocyte migration
across an intact endothelial cell monolayer, and (iii) subsequent
monocyte Interaction with AGE-containing matrix results in
the expression of platelet-derived growth factor. These results
support the existing hypothesis that in vivo-forming glucose-
derived protein adducts can act as signals for the normal
turnover of senescent tissue protein by means of the AGE-
specific receptor system. Time-dependent glucose-Induced dep-
osition of AGEs on matrix proteins may, promote monocyte
Infiltration into the subendothellum. Subsequent AGE-trig-
gered macrophage activation and consequent elaboration of
proliferative factors muy normally coordinate remodeling but
may also lead to the diverse pathogenic changes typical of
arterio- and atherosclerosis In diabetic or aging populations.
Proteins exposed to ambient glucose undergo nonenzymatic
glycosylation. leading to the progressive formation of highly
reactive late addition products termed advanced glycosyia-
tion end products (AGEs). Steady accumulation of AGEs on
proteins with relatively long half-lives in many tissues. cs-
pecially on subendothelial basement-membrane proteins. oc-
curs with normal aging (1) and at an accelerated rate in
diabetes (2), suggesting a possible etiologic role in the patho-
genesis of the vascular complications associated with these
conditions.
Although monocytes are involved in the normal mainte-
nuance and remodeling of the vascular basement membrane
1.31. they have also been causally implicated in the pathogen-
euis of vascular lesions in atherosclerosis (4-6). Monocytes/
macrophages express AGE-specific receptors that mediate
endocytosis and degradation of AGE-modified proteins (7).
After AGE binding and intracellular processing. monocytes
synthesize and secrete growth-promoting cytokines such as
cacheclin/tumor necrosis factor, interleukin 1. and insulin-

payment. This article must therefore be hereby marked ""advertisement""
in accordance with 18 U.S.C. 01734 solely to indicate this fact.
like growth factor 1 (8. 9): Because this mechanism could be
fundamental to vessel-wall tissue homeostasis before the
manifestations of vascular pathology. it was important to
determine whether AGEs promoted monocyte-vessel wall
interactions. leading to monocyte migration into the suben-
dothelium and the subsequent activation of these monocytes.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Preparation of AGE-Modified Bovine Serum Albumin.
AGE-bovine serum albumin (BSA) was prepared by incu-
bating BSA (fraction V. low endotoxin: Bochringer Mann-
heimlin phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) with 50 mM glucose
6-phosphate (Glc-6-P) as described 47). Normal control BSA
was incubated under the same conditions without Glc-6-P.
Fluorescence spectra of AGE-BSA tat 460 nm upon excita.
tion at 390 nm) indicated increased glycosylation as a func-
tion of time (see Results). At 42 days AGE-BSA contained 80
arbitrary fluorescence units (AFL' per 100 ug of protein).
whereas unmodified BSA maintained background levels (4
AFU per 100 ug of protein). For selected experiments
samples (20 mg each) incubated with 50 mM Glc-6-P for 3 and
6 days were reduced with sodium borohydride as described
Preparation of AGE-Modified Low Density Lipoprotein
(LDL). LDL was prepared from pooled normolipidemic
human serum by density-gradient ultracentrifugation (11).
LDL was glycosylated in vitro (AGE-LDL) as described
above for 3 weeks in the presence of the antioxidants
butylated hydroxytoluene (20 uMI and EDTA (0.5 mM) and
under a blanket of N2 in scaled tubes. Oxidized LDL was
prepared by incubating LDL for 3 weeks in the absence of
antioxidants or glucose. The amount of lipid peroxidation
was estimated as thiobarbituric acid-reactive material (12).
and the extent of advanced nonenzy matic glycosylation of
the LDL samples was determined by fluorescence as de-
scribed above. AGE-modified LDL exhibited three times
greater fluorescence (30 AFU per 100 ug of protein) than
unmodified LDL 19 AFU per 100 as of proteinl.
Preparation of Peripheral Nerve Myelin. Human peripheral
nerve myelin obtained at autopsy from a 5-month-old normal
infant. a 63-year-old nondiabetic. and a 61-year-old diabetic
was isolated by standard procedures (13). Fluorescence
studies of the myelin from the 61-year-old diabetic indicated
J-fold greater AGE-levels (156 AFU per 100 ug of protein)
than the age-matched normal individual 150 AFU per 100 ps
of protein). which produced 3.5-fold greater fluorescence
Abbreviations: AGEs. advanced glycosylation end products: FMLP.
N-formylmethionylleucylphenylalanine: LDL. low density lipopro-
tein: PDGF. platelet-derived growth factor: BSA. bovine serum
albumin: AFU, arbitrary fluorescence units: GBSS, Gey's balanced
salt solution; Gk-&-P. glucose 6-phosphate.
PUBLICATIONS
